title: What Epstein’s Emails Claim About Trump’s Knowledge of His Conduct
summary: The House Oversight Committee on Wednesday released more than 20,000 pages of documents from Jeffrey Epstein’s estate. Times reporters provide context on key emails.

title: Epstein Bantered Regularly With Larry Summers
summary: The former Treasury secretary corresponded routinely with Jeffrey Epstein. In one series of exchanges, he sought Mr. Epstein’s advice on how to handle a female acquaintance.

title: Michael Wolff, Chronicler of Elites, Advised Epstein About Trump
summary: Mr. Wolff, it turns out, was enough of an insider to provide advice to Jeffrey Epstein on how to handle his dealings with Donald J. Trump.

title: By Not Funding Food Stamps, Trump Risks Lasting Damage to Safety Net
summary: For the poorest Americans, the expected end to the longest shutdown in history has left doubt and anxiety around the benefits known as SNAP.

title: What to Know About SNAP, America’s Main Food Aid Program
summary: The shutdown brought the scale of the federal food aid program into focus and raised questions about how such a rich country could have so many people on nutrition assistance.

title: As Shutdown Nears End, When Will SNAP and Air Travel Be Back to Normal?
summary: Some programs like SNAP could be restored within hours, while other effects could take longer to unravel.

title: Catholic Bishops Rebuke Trump’s Immigration Tactics in Rare Statement
summary: In a rare statement, the bishops framed the immigration crisis in starkly moral terms. “We feel compelled now in this environment to raise our voices in defense of God-given human dignity,” they said.

title: Federal Judge Calls For Release of Some Immigrants Arrested in Chicago Area
summary: The judge raised concerns that federal agents may have violated terms of a consent decree during their immigration enforcement crackdown in Illinois.

title: City Council Approves Plan That Could Bring 14,700 Homes to Queens
summary: The New York plan would open up 54 blocks of Long Island City, which are mostly warehouses and parking lots, to housing.

title: Adams Makes It Harder for Mamdani to Build Over Elizabeth Street Garden
summary: Mayor Eric Adams’s administration is designating the garden as parkland, which could stymie Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani in his vow to revive the fight to put affordable housing there.

title: Massachusetts Offered a Solution to Housing Shortages. Is It Working?
summary: The Affordable Housing Act designated Cape Cod, Martha’s Vineyard, the Berkshires and other resort towns as “seasonal communities,” making it easier to build homes there for workers.

title: U.S. Mint Presses Final Penny After More Than 200 Years
summary: A long decline into irrelevance ended on Wednesday in Philadelphia.

title: He Died at a School for Disabled People. Decades Later, His Brother Sought Answers.
summary: John Scott was rarely spoken of in his family after he was placed in an institution. After a half-century, his youngest brother set out to learn who he was and what happened to him.

title: Gustavo Petro, the Rebel Turned President Willing to Take on Trump
summary: From his guerrilla roots, Colombia’s president, Gustavo Petro, has long embraced a confrontational style. Now, he has incurred President Trump’s wrath and is facing political fallout at home.

title: 350 Teachers on How Screens Take Over Classrooms, as Early as Kindergarten
summary: Even as schools have banned phones, a Times survey shows how the pandemic-era practice of giving students their own laptops and tablets is here to stay.

title: Michelle Obama’s New Book Is a Historical Document Dressed Up as a Coffee-Table Tome
summary: “The Look” should be studied by generations to come, not because of what it reveals about fashion, but politics.

title: Sally Kirkland, Scene-Stealing Actress, Dies at 84
summary: She received an Oscar nomination for the 1987 film “Anna” but spent much of her prolific career as a go-to supporting actress in movies like “The Sting” and “JFK.”

title: Former Aide to Gavin Newsom Charged With Corruption
summary: Dana Williamson, a top Democratic consultant in California, was accused of conspiring to skim over $200,000 in campaign funds that belonged to a Biden administration official.

title: Iraq’s Prime Minister Leads in Elections but May Struggle to Form a Government
summary: Mohammed al-Sudani pitches himself as someone who can keep Iranian influence in check, but his vote share may not be big enough to ensure a clear political victory.

title: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Head for a Record in 2025, Global Carbon Project Reports
summary: But there are signs that greenhouse gas pollution in China might be slowing, according to a new analysis.

title: Britain Gives Go-Ahead to Smaller Nuclear Reactor in Wales
summary: The government pledged 2.5 billion pounds for initial site work, but the decision to build a small, modular design may disappoint others, including the U.S. nuclear industry.

title: Tim Kaine on Why He Voted to End the Government Shutdown
summary: Extending the government shutdown would not have worked.

title: Democrats Sure Taught Trump a Lesson
summary: It’s one he is unlikely to forget.

title: Jeffrey Epstein Discussed Trump in Emails Released by Congress
summary: Also, the penny was officially retired. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.

title: Former Syrian Security Official Indicted in Austria
summary: Prosecutors say a Syrian security official accused of torture hid in plain sight in Europe for years, protected by Israeli and Austrian intelligence agents.

title: Russian Humanoid Robot Falls on Its Face in Hyped Debut
summary: The robot, known as AIDOL, staggered onstage during a technology showcase in Moscow. Organizers blamed the mishap on calibration and lighting issues.

title: Lucas Museum of Narrative Art in Los Angeles Sets 2026 Opening Date
summary: The 300,000-square-foot building will open Sept. 22 and showcase comic art, illustrations and more across 35 galleries. It began construction in 2018 but faced multiple delays.

title: California Rain Forecast Suddenly Intensifies, Raising Flooding Risks
summary: The storm is expected to move quickly through Northern California by Thursday morning, but forecasters are concerned that it will stall in the southern part of the state.
